coredata.dc:title: Why does sludge-based hydochar activate peroxydisulfate to remove atrazine more efficiently than pyrochar?
coredata.dc:creator: Zhang, Liangliang
Wang, Kai
Yu, Luying

Xue, Gang
coredata.dc:description: Sludge-derived hydrochar (HC) and pyrochar (PC) by hydrothermal and pyrolytic treatments were compared their peroxydisulfate (PDS) activation capacities toward atrazine (ATZ) removal. The HC alone induced lower ATZ removal than PC alone. However, ATZ removal was significantly enhanced in HC/PDS system rather than in PC/PDS system. ATZ removal via adsorption was very low, and singlet oxygen (1O2) primarily contributed to its removal, independently on the PDS addition. Compared to HC, PC possessed stronger electron transfer capacity, exhibiting a higher ATZ removal. After PDS addition, humic substances (HS) in HC (36.3 ± 2.4 mg/g) played a decisive role in enhanced ATZ degradation: PDS excited HS to a triplet state (3HS*); then, PDS and 3HS* together yielded more 1O2. Meanwhile, 3HS* accelerated electron transfer on HC surface. Thus, more electrons were transferred from AZT to 1O2. However, function of small amount of HS in PC (1.5 ± 0.2 mg/g) could be ignored.

Hydrothermal treatment
Hydrochar
PDS
Atrazine

Parameters affecting performance of HC activating PDS for ATZ removal. (a) HT temperature, (b) HT residence time; Reaction conditions in (a) and (b): [ATZ]= 5 mg/L, [HC]= 5 g/L, [PDS]= 1 mM, and pH 5, (c) initial pH in HC/PDS system; reaction conditions: [ATZ]= 5 mg/L, [HC]= 5 g/L, [PDS]= 1 mM, (d) dosage of HC and PDS; reaction conditions: [ATZ]= 5 mg/L, pH 7. The error bar represents the standard deviation of triplicate experiments.

(a) BET, (b) 1O2 detection, EPR spectrum of the HC/TEMP and PC/TEMP system, (c) ·OH and SO4 ·
- detection, EPR spectrum of the HC/DMPO and PC/DMPO system, (d) ATZ removal efficiency in HC and PC system with and without FFA addition after reacting for 20 min. The error bar represents the standard deviation of triplicate experiments.

The detection of free radical and non-radical species via EPR. (a) detection of ·OH, SO4 ·
- in HC/PDS and PC/PDS system, (b) detection of O2 · - in HC/PDS and PC/PDS system, (c) detection of 1O2 in HC and HC/PDS system, (d) detection of 1O2 in PC and PC/PDS system. Experiment conditions: [PC] or [HC]= 2.5 g/L, [PDS]= 1 mM, [ATZ]= 5 mg/L, [DMPO]= 1.5 mM, [TEMP]= 1.0 mM, and pH= 7.

Effect of different scavengers on ATZ degradation. (a) in HC/PDS system, (b) PC/PDS system. Experiment conditions: [HC] or [PC]= 2.5 g/L, [PDS]= 1 mM, [ATZ]= 5 mg/L, [MeOH]= [TBA]= [FFA]= [TBHQ]= 1000 mM.

(a) Comparison of ATZ removal efficiency using HC, PC and Ex-HC, Ex-PC activating PDS, (b) FT-IR spectra of HC, PC and Ex-HC, (c) FT-IR spectra of extracted HS before and after reaction, (d) comparison of ATZ removal efficiency before and after quenching agent (O2 and sorbic acid) was added in HC/PDS and PC/PDS system. The error bar represents the standard deviation of triplicate experiments.

(a) 1O2 generation in HC and Ex-HC system, (b) 1O2 generation in PC and Ex-PC system, (c) the function of 3HS* to 1O2 generation in HC and HC/PDS system, (d) mechanism of ATZ enhanced removal by adding PDS.

head.ce:title: Why does sludge-based hydochar activate peroxydisulfate to remove atrazine more efficiently than pyrochar?

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Donghua University

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Sludge-derived hydrochar (HC) and pyrochar (PC) by hydrothermal and pyrolytic treatments were compared their peroxydisulfate (PDS) activation capacities toward atrazine (ATZ) removal. The HC alone induced lower ATZ removal than PC alone. However, ATZ removal was significantly enhanced in HC/PDS system rather than in PC/PDS system. ATZ removal via adsorption was very low, and singlet oxygen (1O2) primarily contributed to its removal, independently on the PDS addition. Compared to HC, PC possessed stronger electron transfer capacity, exhibiting a higher ATZ removal. After PDS addition, humic substances (HS) in HC (36.3 ± 2.4 mg/g) played a decisive role in enhanced ATZ degradation: PDS excited HS to a triplet state (3HS*); then, PDS and 3HS* together yielded more 1O2. Meanwhile, 3HS* accelerated electron transfer on HC surface. Thus, more electrons were transferred from AZT to 1O2. However, function of small amount of HS in PC (1.5 ± 0.2 mg/g) could be ignored.

ce:section.ce:para: The excess sludge generated from wastewater treatment is very challenge for wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) due to its high moisture content, huge yield, and expensive disposal [1]. Based on high organic content in excess activated sludge, the resource recovery technology from the manufacture of carbonaceous materials applied as catalyst (carbocatalyst) has been rapidly developed recently besides the traditional biogas reclamation via anaerobic sludge digestion.

Up to date, it has been verified that carbocatalysts, including reduced graphene oxide, carbon nanotubes, nanodiamonds, and biochar, can be used as assisting catalysts for persulfate activation to enhance the degradation of pollutants [2,3]. The persulfate-based oxidation process was widely applied since sulfate radicals (SO4 ·
- ) could tolerate a wide range of pH values and had a longer half-life (30–40 μs) and higher redox potential (2.5–3.1 V) compared to hydroxide radical (·OH) (<1 μs, 1.8–2.7 V) [4]. SO4 ·
- can be generated by activating peroxymonosulfate (PMS) or peroxydisulfate (PDS). PDS is cheaper and has higher solubility, higher redox potential, and better stability than PMS, making it more appropriate for in situ applications [2]. The peroxide O-O bond could be cleaved by physical and chemical activation processes, including thermal, UV, and alkali treatments and application of transition metals and carbocatalysts [2,5]. Among them, carbocatalysts exhibited great biocompatibility, high resistance in acidic/alkaline media, large surface area, and flexible electronic transfer, which fostered their rapid development. However, the relatively high cost of graphene oxide and nanotubes limits their practical application. Biochar, which can be formed from waste biomass by thermal treatment, was considered a possible catalytic material due to its general availability, low cost, and excellent catalytic performance [3].

In the recent study, sludge-based biochar for PDS activation has been obtained via the pyrolysis pathway [5–8]. After the pre-dried sludge underwent high-temperature pyrolysis, the carbonized biochar exhibited the persulfate activation performance due to (1) oxygen-containing functional groups on the biochar surface, (2) the defective structure of the material, and (3) the electron transfer mediation between the persulfate and the targeted pollutants [3]. Free radicals, such as SO4 ·
- , ·OH, and superoxide anion (O2
·−), and non-radical oxidants, such as singlet oxygen (1O2), were reported to be involved in the pollutant removal by oxidation [3]. Increasing the pyrolysis temperature and modification of sludge-based biochar by doping heteroatoms with transition metals, nitrogen and sulfur, was considered to improve the catalytic performance [3,9,10].

The preparation of pyrolysis biochar (pyrochar, PC) required dry pretreatment, a professional high-pressure reactor with complex operations, and high energy consumption [11]. Additionally, the modification processes inevitably increase the sludge treatment cost. Compared to the pyrolysis process, hydrothermal (HT) technology, another common thermal treatment method, recovered carbonaceous material at a relatively low HT temperature and avoided the energy-intensive drying pretreatment. A spontaneous and exothermic HT process yielded hydrochar (HC) as the final product [12]. However, the use of HC for PDS activating was not investigated up to date. Our previous study found that magnetic biochar catalyst (MBC) derived from biological sludge and ferric sludge through HT could be applied in the actual dyeing wastewater treatment in an MBC/H2O2 system [11]. Besides the·OH found in this system, O2
·− was also detected, which was attributed to biochar mediation. Therefore, whether HC can be used to activate PDS for pollutant removal or not is worth to study; the difference in the pollutant removal mechanism between PC and HC needs to be determined.

Since the manufacturing conditions of HC and PC are different, their characteristics, such as specific surface structure, interfacial electron transfer resistance, and defect level, are expected to be different, which may affect pollutant removal performance. During a thermochemical treatment, organic matter in sludge underwent dehydration, decarboxylation, polymerization, and aromatization reactions in pyrolysis or hydrothermal processes [5]. Unlike pyrolysis, the hydrothermal process allowed a high moisture content in the sludge, yielding the release of proteins and polysaccharides macromolecules from the sludge phase to the liquid phase. Then, the Maillard reaction occurred, and the humic-like Maillard product was produced and transferred to the hydrochar [13]. Therefore, the carbonaceous compositions of pyrochar and hydrochar are expected to be different. On the other hand, it is still not clear whether the composition affects the activation performance of the PDS and the pollution removal mechanism or not.

Atrazine (ATZ), a typical persistent triazine herbicide, is widely used in agriculture. ATZ can migrate from farmland to groundwater due to its mobility and high chemical stability [14]. It is classified as a Priority A chemical for potential groundwater contamination by the US EPA, and a Group C carcinogen by the United Nations World Health Organization [15]. It has been recently reported that ATZ could be more efficiently and rapidly removed in an SO4 ·
- or ·OH-based oxidation system than in a biodegradation system [14].

In this study, ATZ was selected as a target organic pollutant. Two kinds of sludge-based biochars (PC and HC) were made using pyrolysis and hydrothermal methods, respectively, and the ATZ removal performances of the PDS activating by PC and HC were compared. HC exhibited much better PDS activation ability than PC. We investigated experimental parameters, including HT temperature, residence time, and PDS activating conditions, such as initial pH and biochar/PDS dosage. Furthermore, the mechanisms of the ATZ removal with HC and PC were distinguished in terms of material characteristics, radical generation rule, and contribution of main components in biochars.

Atrazine (99.7%) was supplied by Jiangsu Repont Pesticide Factory Co., Ltd. (China). PDS (Na2S2O8, > 99% purity) was obtained from Aladdin. Methanol (MeOH), tert-butyl alcohol (TBA), furfuryl alcohol (FFA), and tert-butylhydroquinone (TBHQ) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Inc. at HPLC grade. Sorbic acid (> 99.8% purity) was purchased from Rhawn Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 5,5-dimethylpyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) and 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-4-piperidinol (TEMP) trapping reagents were purchased from Sigma Aldrich Inc. Deionized water was used in all experiments.

Excess sludge was obtained from a secondary sedimentation tank in the Songjiang municipal WWTP (Shanghai). The sludge characteristics are summarized in Table S1 in Supplementary Information (SI). The HT apparatus is shown in Fig. S1. HCs and PCs prepared under different conditions were denoted as HC X-Y and PC X-Y; X and Y represent reaction temperature and residence time, respectively.

HT experiments were conducted in HT synthesis reactors (100 mL, Yanzheng Instruments). The heat was supplied by a 220 V electrical heating jacket. The schematic diagram of the reactors is shown in Fig. S1. The hydrochar preparation was implemented according to our previous study [16], and the relevant details are described in SI. Before pyrolysis, the collected sewage sludge was washed three times with deionized water and dried in an oven at 105 °C for 24 h. The dried sludge was transferred to a tube furnace, heated to 600 °C at 10 °C/min, and kept under a nitrogen flow for 2 h. This pyrochar was denoted as PC 600–2. To obtain a uniform particle size, both HC and PC were milled and passed through a 100-mesh sieve before used.

The surface morphology of HC and PC was examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Merlin Compact). Energy-dispersive spectrometry (EDS) was employed to assess the elemental composition on the sample's surface. The textural characteristics of the samples were determined using N2 adsorption/desorption measurements with an Autosorb-iQ gas sorption analyzer, and the specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Surface chemical composition and chemical states were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific). The presence of surface functional groups was investigated using Fourier transform infrared spectrometry (FTIR, Nicolet 6700). The involvement of primary reactive oxygen species (ROS) was detected by electron spin resonance (EPR) technique (Bruker EMXnano Bench-Top electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer, Germany) using different spinning traps. The electron transfer resistance of biochar was revealed by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The relevant method details are described in SI. Raman spectra (inVia-Reflex) were used to detect the surface defect level of the sample.

We applied the EPR technique to verify the existence of ROS. 5,5-dimethylpyrroline-oxide (DMPO) was chosen as a trapping agent for SO4 ·
- and ·OH radicals, while 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-4-piperidinol (TEMP) was used for trapping 1O2. DMPO was chosen to capture O2
·−, but the reaction system was methyl alcohol. Quenching tests were conducted to identify the contribution of reactive radicals and non-radical ROS to the ATZ removal. MeOH and TBA were used to identify the ·OH and SO4 ·
- , while FFA and TBHQ were used to verify the existence of 1O2 and O2
·−, respectively [17,18]. Additionally, oxygen and sorbic acid were reported as selective quenching agents of the triplet-excited state of humic substances (3HS*) [19,20].

We selected HC 220–4 and PC 600–2 samples to compare the PDS activation performance of HC and PC toward the ATZ removal. During the reaction, the concentration of ATZ was 5 mg/L, and the biochar (HC or PC) and PDS dosage was set to 5 g/L and 1 mM, respectively. The ATZ removal efficiency was investigated at pH values of 5, 7, and 9. The detailed experimental procedure is described in SI.

Since we determined that HC 220–4 efficiently activates PDS, parameters that affect the HC PDS activation, including the HT conditions and reaction parameters of the HC/PDS system, were investigated to optimize the HC properties. The experimental procedure is described in SI.

HS was extracted from HC and PC using the NaOH and Na4P2O7 method, according to the reference [21], to assess the effect of the HS component on the PDS activation. The HS-extracted sample was denoted as Ex-HC and Ex-PC, and their PDS activation performances were compared with that of HC and PC following the experimental progress as mentioned above. Additionally, the effect of 3HS* on the ATZ removal was investigated. Oxygen and sorbic acid were used as the quenchers of 3HS*. The experimental details are described in SI.

All experiments were performed in triplicate, and the results were expressed as mean ± standard deviation. An analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to test the significance of results, and p < 0.05 was considered to be statistically significant.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The ATZ removal performance using HC and PC for PDS activation
Evaluation of the performance of HC and PC toward PDS activation
ce:section.ce:para: HC 220–4 and PC 600–2 were selected to activate PDS at different pH values to compare the PDS activation performance of HC and PC since pH was reported to affect the PDS activation significantly [22]. HC or PC without the PDS addition was set as the control group. Moreover, the application of PDS only to remove ATZ was investigated as well. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the ATZ removal rate with HC 220–4 varies in the following order: pH 5 > pH 9 > pH 7; the highest removal rate at pH 5 is only 28.0% after 180 min. However, in the HC/PDS system, ATZ is completely removed at pH 5. As shown in Fig. S2, less than 30% of ATZ is directly oxidized by PDS at different pH values, suggesting that HC 220–4 can efficiently activate PDS to remove ATZ under acidic conditions. In contrast, under neutral and alkaline conditions, the activation performance is insignificant. The ATZ removal efficiency of PC 600–2 (Fig. 1(b)) was 48.0 ± 5.1, 47.2 ± 1.3, and 58.3 ± 7.0% when using pure PC under pH 5, 7, and 9, respectively, after 180 min. After the PDS addition, only a little increase (11.1%) in the ATZ removal rate occurs at pH 5, while the removal efficiently even decreases at pH 7 and 9. This implies that PC 600–2 does not activate PDS efficiently. In previous studies, sludge-based pyrolysis biochar exhibited the capacity to activate PDS for the degradation of organic pollutants; however, additional steps, such as doping with various elements and increasing the pyrolysis temperature, were often applied to improve the activation performance [9,10,22,23]. In this study, the PC 600–2 sample used in this study is prepared under a relatively low pyrolysis temperature without any modification, which might be related to its weak activation capacity and poor ATZ removal performance. On the other hand, the HC 220–4 sample exhibits excellent PDS activation performance at pH 5.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Parameters affecting the performance of HC activating PDS
ce:section.ce:para: When sludge is treated by the hydrothermal method, the characteristics of the derived HC are greatly impacted by the HT temperature and residence time. This may affect the HC performance toward the PDS activation. When temperature increases from 140 to 180 °C, Fig. 2(a), the derived HC exhibits remarkable enhancement in the ATZ removal. Above 200 °C, this temperature effect becomes exhausted. When the HT temperature is set to 200 °C, HC samples are prepared at different HT reaction times (Fig. 2(b)). The ATZ removal efficiency reaches 94.0% within 60 min with the HC sample derived at an HT residence time of more than 3 h. Therefore, the HT operation parameters are optimized, and HC 200–3 is used in the following investigation.

Furthermore, parameters related to reaction conditions in the HC/PDS system are investigated. Because the HC 200–3 properties may differ from those of HC 220–4, which could impact the PDS activation behavior, the influence of the initial pH value on the ATZ degradation using HC 200–3 is assessed, as shown in Fig. 2(c). In contrast to HC 220–4, for HC 200–3 the difference in the ATZ removal efficiency at various pH values becomes small, although it is still slightly better in acidic conditions. The PDS activation by HC 200–3 does not exhibit the pH dependence, suggesting that the HC/PDS system operates within a wide pH range. However, their different responses to pH need further exploration. Since a reasonable ATZ removal efficiency (92.7%) can be achieved within 60 min at neutral pH, the dosages of HC 200–3 and PDS are optimized at pH 7. When the PDS dosage is 1 mM, Fig. 2(d), a lower HC dosage shows a higher ATZ removal efficiency, i.e., for the HC dosage of 2.5, 5, and 10 g/L at 60 min, the ATZ removal efficiency is 97.2 ± 0.3, 89.7 ± 0.7, and 80.2 ± 0.5%. Furthermore, the effect of PDS dosage (0.5, 1, and 2 mM) on the ATZ removal performance with a certain amount of HC is explored, Fig. S3. When the HC dosage is 2.5 g/L, 1.0 mM PDS is enough to achieve complete ATZ removal. In contrast, when the HC dosage is higher (5.0 and 10.0 g/L), a higher amount PDS (2 mM) is demanded to obtain good ATZ removal. Therefore, ATZ can be completely removed under the following experimental parameters: HC 200–3 of 2.5 g/L, PDS of 1 mM, and pH 7.

Remarkably, a higher HC amount is disadvantageous for the ATZ removal when the PDS amount is constant, and a higher amount of HC should correspond to a higher PDS amount. Oppositely, Yin et al. found that the sulfamethoxazole degradation efficiency enhanced from 50.4% to 69.6%, 94.6%, and 98.3% when the dosage of sludge-derived pyrolysis biochar increased from 0.5 to 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 g/L under the PDS dosage of 1.5 mM, which was explained by more active sites for the PDS activation provided by a higher biochar amount [24]. We show that the optimal dosage combination rule is different, suggesting different PDS activation mechanisms, as discussed in the following part.

ce:section.ce:section-title: ATZ removal pathways using HC and PC
ATZ removal pathway using only HC and PC
ce:section.ce:para: ATZ is partially removed when only HC 200–3 or PC 600–2 are used, and the PC system exhibits a higher ATZ degradation rate. Firstly, we have considered the ATZ removal attributed to adsorption. The specific surface of 34.2 and 8.78 m2/g is determined for HC 200–3 and PC 600–2 via adsorption and desorption measurements, Fig. 3(a). The specific surface of PC is similar to the value reported in the literature [7], which is possibly due to the adhesion of the tar produced in the sludge pyrolysis process to the surface of the biochar, blocking its pores [25]. HC exhibits a larger specific surface while exhibiting a lower ATZ removal rate, implying that simple physical adsorption is not the main reason for the ATZ removal. Then, possible free radicals, such as·OH and SO4·-, or non-radical oxidant, such as 1O2, are detected via EPR. When HC or PC are added to the ATZ solution, after reacting for 10 min, 1O2 is detected using TEMP radical trapping agent, and·OH and SO4 -·are determined by DMPO. Fig. 3(b) and (c), show that 1O2 is generated, and the HC system shows a relatively higher 1O2 content than the PC system. Additionally, the PC and HC systems do not show·OH and SO4·- generation. To further verify whether the produced 1O2 participates in the ATZ removal or not, FFA, the 1O2 quenching agent is applied at the beginning of the reaction, and the ATZ removal efficiency is detected after reacting for 20 min [26]. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the removal efficiency decreases from 11.8% to 1.7% in the HC system and declines from 19.2% to 5.2% in the PC system, meaning that the ATZ removal is mostly induced by the chemical oxidation pathway rather than physical adsorption, even without the PDS addition.

ce:section.ce:section-title: ATZ removal pathway in HC/PDS and PC/PDS systems
ce:section.ce:para:
As described in Figs. 1(a) and 2(d), HC but not PC can activate PDS. Free radicals (·OH, SO4 ·
- , and O2 · -) are detected in HC/PDS and PC/PDS systems, and Fig. 4(a) and (b) show that no obvious ·OH, SO4 ·
- , and O2 · - are generated. Similar to pure HC and PC systems, the non-radical oxidant 1O2 is detected in both HC/PDS and PC/PDS systems, and its relative content (expressed via intensity) vs. reaction time (10, 30, and 60 min) is monitored, Fig. 4(c) and (d). As 1O2 can be generated in pure PC and HC systems, the 1O2 intensity is compared between the biochar system and biochar/PDS system after 10 min. Fig. 4(c) shows that the 1O2 intensity in the HC system is higher than in the HC/PDS system after 10 min. Then, its content slightly increases at 30 min and remains constant at 60 min in the HC/PDS system. However, the 1O2 intensity in the PC/PDS system is similar to that in the PC system after 10 min; it increases further at 30 min and remains stable at 60 min. This suggests that 1O2 is consumed in the HC/PDS system to participate in the ATZ degradation reaction, resulting in the quick ATZ removal. However, in the PC/PDS system, 1O2 cannot be efficiently used.

Afterward, the quenching experiments are conducted to identify ROS involved in the ATZ degradation. Generally, MeOH and TBA are often used as radical probes to distinguish SO4 ·
- and ·OH. TBA primarily tends to react with ·OH rather than with SO4 ·
-
[27]. As shown in Fig. 5(a) and (b), the addition of MeOH and TBA does not significantly affect the ATZ degradation, implying that SO4 ·
- and ·OH are not involved in the ATZ degradation, consistent with the EPR results where SO4 ·
- and ·OH are not detected in the HC/PDS and PC/PDS systems. After adding the 1O2 scavenger, FFA, at the beginning of the reaction, the ATZ degradation in HC/PDS and PC/PDS systems is almost terminated, Fig. 5, confirming that 1O2 mainly contributes to the ATZ removal. Yin et al. also found that sulfamethoxazole degradation by the nonradical 1O2 is the main degradation pathway rather than SO4 ·- oxidation in biochar/PDS system [24]. Moreover, TBHQ, as an O2 · - scavenger, is added at the beginning of the reaction [17], inhibiting the ATZ degradation and implying that O2 · - is related to this oxidation process. However, O2 · - is not detected, Fig. 4(b), probably because O2 · - represents intermediate species toward the 1O2 formation in the biochar system. Therefore, O2 · - is involved in the ATZ degradation reaction but cannot be detected.

As discussed above, although 1O2 is mainly involved in the ATZ removal in the pure biochar and the biochar/PDS systems, it needs to be clarified why PC yields a higher ATZ removal than HC and why HC rather than PC can efficiently activate PDS to remove ATZ. We explored this in the following part.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Why does PC induce a higher ATZ removal rate than HC?
ce:section.ce:para:
When using biochar to remove ATZ, it interacts with the pollutant directly. Therefore, the biochar characteristics directly impact the ATZ removal performance. SEM micrographs show the surface morphology of HC 200–3 and PC 600–2, Fig. 6(a) and (b). HC exhibits a rough surface with small particles, while the PC surface is smooth and has a flat shape. This is consistent with the BET results, Fig. 3(a), that HC has a relatively higher specific surface area than PC. However, HC's higher specific surface area cannot cause stronger ATZ removal via adsorption, as verified above. Liang et al. revealed that mineral constituents in sludge-derived biochar played a crucial role in persulfate activation for phenol degradation [8]. Especially, Fe in biochar was beneficial for the catalytic performance toward the pollutant degradation [8,28]. The elemental mapping is used to detect the surface composition of samples. Fig. S4 shows that HC and PC are primarily composed of C, O, Al, Si, and Fe. The weight fractions of Fe in HC and PC are 26.52% and 27.58%, respectively. The high Fe content in biochar is related to the ferric salt addition to facilitate the phosphate removal in WWTP. Furthermore, an XPS study is conducted to assess the chemical state of the iron species. Fe2+ and Fe3+, Fig. 6(c) and (d), are present in the amounts of 59.73% and 40.27% in HC, and 47.98% and 52.02% in PC, respectively, suggesting the dispersion of Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 in HC and PC. It was reported that the generated Maillard product was responsible for the Fe3+ reduction in the HT process [16]. In this study, the reducing N2 atmosphere induces a partial reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ in the pyrolysis process. Although the Fe2+ and Fe3+contents are different in HC and PC, this difference can hardly cause such a big discrepancy in the PDS activation. Additionally, previous studies demonstrated that Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 could effectively activate PMS and accelerate the generation of SO4 ·
- to degrade organic contaminant [3,8]. However, SO4 ·
- is not detected in this study when iron species exist in biochars, implying that Fe in HC and PC is not the main reason that causes different activation performances.

In this study, the non-radical process via 1O2 made the main contribution to the ATZ removal. Recent studies have indicated that EIS could identify whether a non-radical process was mediated by electron transfer and assess the interfacial transfer resistance of electrons or ions on the catalyst electrode [6,29]. Fig. 6(e) shows the EIS spectra of HC and PC. The diameter of the Nyquist semicircle of PC is smaller than that of HC, indicating that the charge transfer resistance of PC is lower. Raman spectroscopy is usually applied for determining the degree of defects and structural distortion of carbon materials. The I(D)/I(G) ratio reflects the defective degree of carbon materials. Fig. 6(f) features two dominant peaks at ~1330 cm−1 (D band) and ~1590 cm−1 (G band), indicating the vibrational mode induced by the disordered structure and the E2 g vibration of sp2-hybridized carbon network, respectively [30]. The intensity ratio of I(D)/I(G) for HC and PC is 0.71 and 0.93, implying that more defects are created in PC in the pyrolysis process. The defective structure could serve as an active site for pollutant oxidation [22,30] and promote electron transfer [6]. PC possesses a lower interfacial transfer resistance and a higher defective degree than HC, accelerating the electron transfer from ATZ to 1O2, resulting in a higher ATZ removal rate in the PC system.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Why does HC activate PDS more efficiently than PC toward the ATZ degradation?
ce:section.ce:para: After the PDS addition, the HC/PDS system shows excellent performance for the ATZ removal, totally different from pure HC. However, the PC/PDS and pure PC systems do not significantly differ in the pollutant degradation. From the above-mentioned characteristic comparison, the perspectives of surface morphologies, iron content, iron species, interfacial electron transfer, and the defect structure cannot explain this behavior. When sludge is manufactured to carbon material through hydrothermal and pyrolysis methods, it undergoes different carbonization extents, yielding inevitable differences in the carbonaceous components. During the pyrolysis process, the dried sludge under high temperature undergoes deamination, dehydrogenation, and aromatic condensation with heterocyclic-N production [31]. It is challenging to detect specific organic constituents in pyrochar because they are affected by feedstock and pyrolysis conditions. In the hydrothermal treatment, the high moisture of sludge induces the hydrothermal reaction at the solid sludge and liquid phases. Condensation reactions, including dehydration, decarboxylation, and demethanation, occur in the solid phase. Additionally, main organic components, such as proteins and carbohydrates, are partially released from the sludge to the liquid phase, experiencing the Maillard reaction to form dark brown HS. Then, HS could precipitate toward the solid biochar and became the constituent of HC [13,32]. HS was also reported in pyrochar; however, its content decreased with the pyrolysis temperature, and the HS amount could be even negligible at pyrolysis temperatures of 300 and 400 °C [33]. When using the sludge-based pyrolysis as a catalyst, the pyrolysis temperature is always higher than 500 °C, and herein, 600 °C. Therefore, from the perspective of organic composition, the most obvious difference between HC and PC is the HS content. It was proved that HS in solution influenced the PDS activation performance [25,34]. Thus, the role of HS in HC playing in PDS activation needs to be further explored.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of humic-like substance in HC on the ATZ removal in the HC/PDS system
ce:section.ce:para: Firstly, the content of HS in HC and PC is detected. The HS is extracted from biochar, and the HS amount expressed as TOC in HC is 36.3 ± 2.4 mg/g, while it is only 1.5 ± 0.2 mg/g in PC. To explore the HS function in the PDS activation, HS is extracted from HC and PC, and then these extracted biochars (Ex-HC, Ex-PC) are used for the PDS activation to degrade ATZ. Fig. 7(a) shows that the ATZ removal efficiency is only 3.0% in the Ex-HC/PDS system, while it is almost completely removed in the HC/PDS system; however, there is no remarkable difference in the ATZ removal between the PC/PDS and Ex-PC/PDS systems (p = 0.28). This demonstrated that HS in HC significantly impacts the PDS activation. In this study, HC 200–3 and HC 220–4 were found to response differently towards pH values when activating PDS. The HS content in HC 220–4 is detected as well and the result is 24.5 ± 1.6 mg/g, which is lower than that of HC 200–3. It was reported that the binding of hydrophobic compounds by HS generally decreased with increase in pH [35,36]. In this study, the ATZ is speculated to be binded by HS on HC; then the produced 1O2 takes part in ATZ degradation. As to HC 220–4, under lower pH value (pH=5), the HS has relatively strong binding capacity on ATZ, and good ATZ removal efficiency is achieved. With pH increasing to 7 and 9, the weakened binding capacity results in ATZ removal decrease. As to HC 200–3, the HS content is 32.5% higher than that of HC 220–4. Its binding capacity on ATZ is speculated to be enough under three different pH values. This is one possible explanation for their different PDS activating performances. However, their different responses to pH need further exploration via further experiments.

As HS contains many diverse functional groups, we assessed and compared the functional groups of HC, Ex-HC, PC, and Ex-PC using FT-IR method, Fig. 7(b). The adsorption bands of HC and Ex-HC spectrum are similar, and Ex-HC exhibits a lower relative intensity than HC, probably because the content of functional groups is decreased upon the extraction step. As the FTIR spectra of PC and Ex-PC almost overlap, only the PC spectrum is shown. PC features fewer functional groups and weaker intensity than HC. These major functional groups are observed in HC with apparent high-intensity peaks, verifying humic acid in HC. PC does not have evident peaks at 2854, 2925, and 1455 cm−1, and the intensity of peaks at 1635 and 1405 cm−1 decreases significantly. These peaks are related to the HS functional groups [37]. The main characteristic bands are analyzed as follows: (1) 2925 and 2854 cm−1 are ascribed to C–H stretching of aliphatic methylene groups, belonging to long-chain aliphatic components. Their intensities are strong in the FTIR spectra of HC and Ex-HC, while they are very weak in PC, suggesting that some components with low boiling points are removed at the high pyrolysis temperature, yielding HC with a higher aliphaticity degree, consistent with the elemental analysis with a higher H/C value (Table S2). (2) 1635 cm−1 refers to the aromatic CC skeletal vibration, CO stretching of quinine, and N–H bending, and the intensity of HC and Ex-HC is much higher than that of PC. (3) the peak ~1454 cm−1 originates from the C–H bending of CH3 groups; the peak intensity of HC and Ex-HC is weak and even disappears in PC, corresponding to the decomposition of lipid from the sludge [33]. (4) the peak at 1405 cm−1 is related to -OH and -CO deformation from alcoholic and phenolic -OH and -COO- symmetric stretching vibration [38]. (5) the band at ~1085 cm−1 originates from the C–O stretching of polysaccharide or the Si–O stretching [38]. The previous study has verified that most polysaccharides in sludge participated in the Maillard reaction during hydrothermal treatment [13], suggesting that this band plausibly originates from the Si–O stretching. The FTIR analysis reveals that the HC surface has more functional groups related to HS than PC, explaining their different PDS activation performances.

To directly test the function of HS for the PDS activation and judge whether the functional groups participate in the ATZ degradation or not, the extracted-HS is added to the ATZ solution. Then, PDS is added to initiate the reaction. However, the ATZ concentration cannot be detected accurately because of the disruption induced by the dark brown color of HS, even after the HS is precipitated. Then, the extracted-HS after the reaction for 2 h is collected, and HS samples before and after the reaction are investigated using FTIR, Fig. 7(c). The main characteristic bands are related to HS [37]. The bands and intensity do not change significantly, indicating that the HS functional groups do not participate in the ATZ degradation reaction.

HS could act as a photocatalyst via forming different active intermediates, and 3HS* played a crucial role. 1O2 could be formed through an energy transfer from 3HS* to O2, playing an important role in the contaminant transformation [39]. Also, 3HS* could activate peroxymonosulfate for pollutant degradation [34]. Therefore, we may speculate on the existence of HS in HC as 3HS* and whether it plays an important role in the HC/PDS system or not. Sorbic acid and oxygen are reported as satisfactory quenching agents for triplet-excited states of organic compounds [19]. The 3HS* quenching test is conducted as described in SI. The ATZ removal is markedly inhibited after introducing oxygen and adding ascorbic acid in the HC/PDS system, Fig. 7(d). In contrast, in the PC/PDS system, when oxygen exists, the ATZ removal does not show a significant decrease, and there is only a little decline when sorbic acid is used. This suggested that 3HS* plays an important role in the HC/PDS system. Since PC has only a small amount of HS, the HS role in the PC/PDS system can be ignored.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Mechanism of the HS impact on the PDS activation
ce:section.ce:para: When PDS is added, ATZ is totally removed in the HC/PDS system, while the ATZ removal efficiency in the PC/PDS system is similar to the PC system. Thus, we pose a question why do HC/PDS and PC/PDS systems show different behaviors after the PDS addition? The carbonaceous materials in biochar were reported to be responsible for the 1O2 generation [10]. Both HC and PC exhibit the 1O2 generation. However, their carbonaceous compositions are different, since HC contains HS and PC does not, suggesting that the source of the 1O2 production is different. As revealed in Fig. 8(a) and (b), after extracting the HS from HC and PC, the relative amount of 1O2 produced by Ex-HC is lower than that of HC, while Ex-PC and PC exhibit a similar level in the 1O2 generation. This verifies that 1O2 in HC is partly generated from HS, while almost all the 1O2 in PC originates from non-HS carbonaceous substances.

After the PDS addition, HS plays a decisive role in the ATZ removal, Fig. 7(a). Also, its excited state makes an important contribution to the ATZ removal (Fig. 7(d)). Since HS and 1O2 also exist in the pure HC system, it needs to be revealed why HS does not play the same role in this system. Does the excited state form during the HT process or after the PDS addition? The excited-state quenching test verifies that 3HS* exists in the HC/PDS system, Fig. 7(d). Then, as a quenching agent, sorbic acid is added in the pure HC system at the beginning of the reaction. The results show that the ATZ removal behavior does not change after using sorbic acid (Fig. S5), implying that HC alone does not feature the function of 3HS* , suggesting that the 3HS* of HC is formed after the PDS addition.

In the previous study, 3HS* was often found in the photocatalytic system under sunlight excitation and exerted important impact on pollutant removal [19,34,40,41]. Humic acid excited by visible light could activate PMS to generate reactive species, including 1O2, which was beneficial for the bisphenol A degradation [34]. Therefore, keeping in mind the function of 3HS*, it is expected that the 1O2 amount in the HC/PDS system is higher than that in the HC system. To check this hypothesis, we added the triplet-excited state quenching agent sorbic acid in both HC and HC/PDS systems and compared the generated 1O2 amount with the case without sorbic acid. Since the ATZ existence consumes 1O2, as shown in Fig. S6, ATZ is not added in the HC and HC/PDS systems when exploring the rule of 1O2 generation. As depicted in Fig. 8(c), the intensity of the 1O2 peak remarkably increases in the HC/PDS system compared to the pure HC system, suggesting that PDS triggers more extensive 1O2 generation. Furthermore, after the introduction of sorbic acid, the 1O2 intensity in the HC system does not change significantly. However, sorbic acid decreases the 1O2 amount in the HC/PDS system dramatically, implying that 3HS* also contributes to the 1O2 production.

The 1O2 can be formed through energy transfer from excited state organic matter to O2 in natural waters [41]. In the present study, the PDS-induced 3HS* induces enhanced generation of 1O2, and the 3HS* can activate PDS to generate 1O2 [34]. As summarized in Fig. 8(d), under the effect of 3HS*, the 1O2 can be formed via energy transfer to O2 and PDS decomposition. It is worth noting that 1O2 also exists in the HC system, but it cannot be used efficiently; however, 1O2 can be consumed after the PDS addition, Fig. 4(c). Pozdnyakov et al. found that in the HS-assisted photodegradation system [19], the non-bonding nitrogen electron (N-electron) tends to transfer electron to 3HS*, which was beneficial for imipramine degradation. ATZ also possesses a non-bonding nitrogen atom so that electron can be transferred from ATZ to 3HS* on the HC surface. Moreover, quinone moieties within HS could be photo-activated, participating in various redox reactions as active electron shuttles and accelerating the electron transfer between HS and oxidants [34,40]. In this study, FT-IR spectra in Fig. 7(c) show that quinone moieties exist in HS on the HC surface (peak at 1635 cm−1). Therefore, it can be speculated that the PDS-induced 3HS* improved the electron transfer capacity of HC. Resultantly, the produced 1O2 can be consumed by accepting the electron from ATZ. The possible mechanism of the enhanced ATZ removal by the PDS addition is proposed and summarized in Fig. 8(d).

As discussed above, when PDS is added, firstly, the HS on HC is excited by PDS. Then, 3HS* triggers the PDS decomposition of a higher amount of 1O2; meanwhile, 3HS* might improve the electron transfer capacity. Therefore, a relatively higher amount of 1O2 is efficiently consumed by accepting electrons from ATZ, remarkably increasing the final ATZ removal. This mechanism can also explain the phenomenon in Fig. 2(d) that higher amount of HC should match higher dosage of PDS, because more PDS is needed to excite the higher content of HS. As for the PC/PDS system, the effect of the tiny amount of HS on PC can be ignored. Moreover, the electron transfer capacity is not improved but is probably inhibited because of the inactivation of active sites due to the PDS coverage. Therefore, the ATZ removal is not improved in the PC/PDS system comparing to that in the pure PC system.

The sludge-derived HC and PC were compared toward the PDS activation for the ATZ removal. It was revealed that HC induced a lower ATZ degradation efficiency than PC when only pure HC and PC are used. However, after introducing PDS, HC rather than PC can efficiently activate the PDS to strongly enhance the ATZ removal. Further investigation revealed that HC obtained under at an HT temperature of 200 °C and a residence time of 3 h yielded excellent ATZ removal. The optimal reaction conditions were the dosage of HC 200–3 and PDS of 2.5 g/L and 1 mM, respectively, under neutral conditions. The EPR and quenching test manifested that 1O2 dominated the ATZ removal in pure biochar and biochar/PDS systems. When using pure HC and PC, the PC surface possessed a lower interfacial transfer resistance and a higher defective level, providing the more efficient electron transfer from ATZ to 1O2, which explained the higher ATZ degradation rate in PC system. After the PDS addition, the PDS excited HS on HC to 3HS* , which produced more 1O2 via an energy transfer to oxygen or the PDS decomposition. Additionally, 3HS* served as an electron shuttle to improve the electron transfer on the HC surface. Then, the produced 1O2 could be consumed by accepting the electron from ATZ. Therefore, HS in HC played a decisive role in HC/PDS toward enhanced ATZ removal, while the PC/PDS system exhibited no significant improvement comparing to the pure PC system because of the insufficient HS presence.
